page.title: 02BACKGROUND (CONT.)
page.content: Binfield derives its name from the coarse grass in this clearing of Windsor Forest. Windsor Forest was divided into 16 ('walkes') and ('Binfield walk') was stocked with red and fallow deer for the king to hunt. In the 16th century Sir Henry Neville, the keeper, lived at Billingbear. Binfield Lodge was one of James I's hunting lodges. Binfield Manor is located next to the Forest Road. In 1769 a Turnpike Trust improved the Forest Road. This was already an established 'drovers road' along which animals were driven to market. The improved road enhanced the importance of 2 inns: the Stag and Hounds in Binfield where an ancient hollow elm is said to mark the centre of Windsor Forest and The Four Horse Shoes in Warfield, now a private house.
